content.raw: I might be wrong but I believe there's nothing to prevent the publication of the Ignition messages at a higher frequency than the `rate` requested. The rate seems to be effective only when there are timeouts, so when nothing is actually happening.
content.html: I might be wrong but I believe there's nothing to prevent the publication of the Ignition messages at a higher frequency than the rate requested. The rate seems to be effective only when there are timeouts, so when nothing is actually happening.

content.raw: Just checking: If we're publishing at 60Hz. and I'm not touching the joystick, I get all messages with the same timestamp (from the last action). Is this expected?
content.html: Just checking: If we're publishing at 60Hz. and I'm not touching the joystick, I get all messages with the same timestamp (from the last action). Is this expected?
Very minor tweak in 03d9440.

content.raw: Thanks. An alternative would have this run as a standalone program, since it doesn't really need to access anything in the physics. That would make it less convenient to load and parametrize though...
content.html: Thanks. An alternative would have this run as a standalone program, since it doesn't really need to access anything in the physics. That would make it less convenient to load and parametrize though...

content.raw: Ahh thanks, I should have realized...
this branch was out of date. I've merged with gazebo9 to get the ffmpeg4 fix
content.html: this branch was out of date. I've merged with gazebo9 to get the ffmpeg4 fix

content.raw: I honestly copied the logic from ROS. However, their use case would (typically) run this in its own process. In our case, your right that a 10s block would be annoying. I'll reduce this to 2 seconds.
content.html: I honestly copied the logic from ROS. However, their use case would (typically) run this in its own process. In our case, your right that a 10s block would be annoying. I'll reduce this to 2 seconds.
